heading: searching for et with your pc
subheading: the seti@home project will soon release beta software for seeking traces of alien intelligence. over 400,000 people have signed up to create what could be the world's most powerful distributed supercomputer. by leander kahney.
author: leander kahney
text: finally, a screensaver with a purpose. now anyone can join the global search for et. on 17 may, the search for extraterrestrial intelligence will release seti@home: beta software for windows and macintosh systems which will use spare cpu cycles on desktop pcs to hunt through radio signals beamed at earth for signs of alien intelligence."there's a small but captivating possibility that your computer will detect the faint murmur of a civilization beyond earth," the project states on its site.the software downloads radio data from seti@home's central computers in berkeley, california, and then sifts through it, looking for a nonrandom pattern; anything that stands out from the white noise of the universe's background radio transmissions.the free software acts like a screensaver when the computer is sitting idle, displaying graphs of the calculations the machine is grinding through.seti@home is hoping to harness the power of hundreds of thousands of machines connected to the internet. more than 400,000 people across the globe have signed up to take part."we think [the project] will be the world's biggest supercomputer, about 100 times more powerful than our biggest supercomputer," said the project's chief scientist, dan werthimer, a professor at the university of california at berkeley's space sciences laboratory.the seti experiment is related to, but not part of, the independently funded seti institute.seti@home has been gathering raw data since last october from the arecibo radio telescope in puerto rico, the world's largest radio telescope, which was built into the bowl of an extinct volcano. to give an idea of its size, werthimer explained that it could hold 10 billion bowls of corn flakes."it's collecting data 24 hours a day, all year round," werthimer said. "it would be impossible to sift through it on our own. the solution is to get everyone to help."
